channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Corbyn 'cannot support air strikes'
item.description: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn writes to his MPs saying he cannot back UK air strikes in Syria - prompting a warning of shadow cabinet resignations.

item.title: Syria air strikes 'will make us safer'
item.description: David Cameron puts the case for air strikes against IS in Syria - with Jeremy Corbyn at odds with half his shadow cabinet on the issue.

item.title: Russia plans sanctions against Turkey
item.description: Russia is preparing wide-ranging economic sanctions against Turkey after the downing of one of its jets, Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev says.

item.title: Lord Coe ends association with Nike
item.description: IAAF president Lord Coe ends his 38-year ambassadorial role with American sportswear giant Nike.

item.title: Number of untaxed UK vehicles doubles
item.description: The number of vehicles without road tax - Vehicle Excise Duty (VED) - doubled to 560,000 after the paper tax disc was abolished in October 2014.

item.title: BBC Three to move online from February
item.description: The BBC Trust formally approves proposals to move BBC Three online only from February, on the condition that programmes will be shown on BBC One and Two.

item.title: 'Very significant' cuts still to come
item.description: "Very significant" government spending cuts will be imposed before the next general election, the Institute for Fiscal Studies think tank warns.

item.title: Net migration to UK hits record 336,000
item.description: Annual net migration to the UK reaches a record 336,000, with 294,000 people arriving in the UK for work, figures show.

item.title: Families win carers' benefit cap case
item.description: The government discriminated against disabled people by failing to exempt some unpaid carers from the cap on benefits, the High Court rules.

item.title: Trump mocks disabled reporter
item.description: Republican presidential contender Donald Trump is criticised for mocking a disabled New York Times reporter.

item.title: Cult leader tells of 'satellite warfare machine'
item.description: A communist accused of presiding over a cult in London tells a court he can 'initiate' an "electronic satellite warfare machine" called Jackie.

item.title: Grandson killer jailed for drowning
item.description: A man who drowned his nine-year-old grandson in the bath is jailed for life for the boy's murder.

item.title: VIDEO: Citizen journalists capture life in Raqqa under Islamic State
item.description: Citizen journalists are the main - and often only - source of information about life in a city controlled by the so-called Islamic State.

item.title: VIDEO: Afghan rapper escaped child marriage
item.description: The BBC speaks to Sonita Alizadeh, who started rapping after she was nearly sold as a bride by her family.

item.title: VIDEO: Baby found in NY church nativity manger
item.description: A newborn baby has been called ''a miracle child'' after being found in the nativity manger of the Holy Child Jesus Church in Queens, New York.

item.title: VIDEO: Australian man drives into bushfire
item.description: A man who was filming on his phone while driving past a bushfire says he is lucky to be alive, after the flames engulfed his car.

item.title: VIDEO: Man lives after demolition goes wrong
item.description: A demolition worker has survived after a 113-year-old smokestack fell on him in Alabama, US.

item.title: VIDEO: Switzerland’s vanishing natural wonder
item.description: Striking drone footage shows the extent of the retreat of Switzerland's Rhone Glacier, as scientists warn such magisterial ice-masses will have almost vanished by the end of the century.

item.title: VIDEO: Giant green 'pants' light up Tiverton
item.description: Tiverton in Devon has unveiled its new Christmas lights - but many local residents have mocked them saying the lights look like underpants hanging on a washing line.

item.title: VIDEO: What is Black Friday?
item.description: The BBC's Emma Simpson looks at the origin of the shopping phenomenon known as Black Friday and its impact on the UK economy.

item.title: A difficult week in Brussels
item.description: As Brussels gets back to normal, after a four-day lockdown, a sense of uncertainty and discontent lingers, says Chris Morris.

item.title: Oldham is a fundamental test for Labour
item.description: The Oldham West and Royton by-election will be the first major test of public opinion for new Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, says Mark Mardell.

item.title: Tax changes in the pipeline
item.description: Our tax affairs will be organised digitally in the future, Chancellor George Osborne says, but it does not mean it is getting any simpler. So what are the changes?

item.title: Shrinking to Zero: The Raspberry Pi gets smaller
item.description: Launched in 2012, the Raspberry Pi has become Britain's most successful homegrown computer. Now it's getting smaller and cheaper.

item.title: Adele announces first tour since 2011
item.description: Adele is to embark on a UK and European arena tour next year - her first tour for five years.

item.title: Top US academy bans pillow fights
item.description: Huge pillow fights among US cadets to mark the end of summer training at the prestigious West Point military academy are to be banned.

item.title: Toss to be scrapped in county cricket
item.description: The mandatory coin toss is to be scrapped in both divisions of the County Championship next season.

item.title: North signs new Northampton deal
item.description: Wales wing George North signs a new contract with Premiership club Northampton Saints.

item.title: 'We shouldn't have to rely on strategy'
item.description: Lewis Hamilton on preparing for the final race of the season, the strategy of Formula 1 and the attraction of Nascar.

item.title: 'Man Utd too rigid under Van Gaal'
item.description: Manchester United are suffering from a "lack of freedom" under Louis van Gaal, says former club coach Rene Meulensteen.

item.title: Retailers brace for Black Friday frenzy
item.description: UK retailers are gearing up for the Black Friday shopping phenomenon, with analysts predicting record online sales.

item.title: Barclays fined for poor client checks
item.description: Banking giant Barclays has been fined £72m for failing to conduct proper checks on very rich clients because it did not want to inconvenience them.

item.title: Salmond's portrait unveiling criticised
item.description: Former first minister Alex Salmond is criticised for unveiling a new portrait in Edinburgh on the day MPs discussed possible military action in Syria.

item.title: McDonnell defends Chairman Mao quote
item.description: Labour's John McDonnell defends his decision to quote Chairman Mao in his Spending Review response, saying the stunt was a joke.

item.title: One in five children obese in Year 6
item.description: One in 10 children was obese at the start of primary school in England last year but one in five was obese by the end, according to new figures.

item.title: Junior doctor dispute to go to Acas
item.description: The government has agreed to talks at Acas in the junior doctors' dispute - but the strikes have not been called off.

item.title: Plans to regulate madrassas published
item.description: The government has set out draft plans to regulate madrassas.

item.title: Nurseries warn over 30-hours pledge
item.description: Nurseries say they will struggle to meet the 30-hour free childcare pledge for pre-school children.

item.title: Pirate makes film to avoid being sued
item.description: A convicted Czech software pirate agrees to make an anti-piracy film in order to avoid being sued by the firms whose software he pirated.

item.title: The truth about Facebook quizzes
item.description: Much press attention has been devoted to a Facebook quiz which asked for large swathes of data in return for a word cloud of your most used words, but do we really need to worry?

item.title: Ultrasound scans brain in micro 3D
item.description: Scientists use ultrasound to scan the blood vessels of an entire rat brain in microscopic 3D detail, pioneering a technique they say will improve cancer and stroke diagnosis.

item.title: Lead poisons '100,000 birds annually'
item.description: About 100,000 wetland birds are killed every year from poisoning by discarded lead ammunition, say scientists.

item.title: New Gremlins film 'not a remake'
item.description: Actor Zach Galligan says the new Gremlins movie in development will not be a reboot or a remake and that he has a "decent chance" of reprising his role from the first two films.

item.title: DJ's children sue for wrongful death
item.description: Three of US DJ Casey Kasem's children and his brother sue the late star's widow for wrongful death in the latest move in a bitter family feud.

item.title: Do terrorists really think they're going to win?
item.description: The history of terrorism has much to teach about what drives the current wave of radicals.

item.title: The trouble with saying you don't want children
item.description: When Holly Brockwell spoke to the BBC about her decision not to have children, the abuse she received was so extreme she deactivated her Twitter account.

item.title: Julia Margaret Cameron at the V&A
item.description: The V&A marks the bicentenary of Julia Margaret Cameron's birth

item.title: Monir Farmanfarmaian: A life in art
item.description: The work of91-year-old artist Monir Farmanfarmaian

item.title: What is the UK doing about Syria?
item.description: 11 key questions on what the UK should do about Syria

item.title: What is the Little Red Book?
item.description: What exactly is the Little Red Book?

item.title: Does the UK have a problem with whiplash?
item.description: Why does the UK have so many whiplash cases?

item.title: Why Greeks are exhuming their parents
item.description: The country where people are exhumed after three years

item.title: Is this the subject with the most baffling jargon?
item.description: Is this the subject with the most baffling jargon?

item.title: Leaving the UK and going 'home' to Ghana
item.description: Why young professionals are moving from London to Accra

item.title: 'I went blind and feel partly to blame'
item.description: 'I went blind after neglecting my diabetes'

item.title: Buster, bust-ups & Boycott of tennis
item.description: Great Britain's run to 1978 Davis Cup final was far from dull
